text: the rise of Bottega Veneta from a
company that made bags latticework to a
company that really expresses the soul
of what fashion is about today is thanks
to one man Thomas my ear he had the
vision to understand in an era of bling
that there was another way of dressing
and looking and being it's based on
himself but it's for everyone is for a
global world and it's about objects
which are done to be as economic as
possible as useful to make people's
lives better and at the same time to
give them strength so that their day
passes with these useful objects whether
they're on the back or in the hand
Thomas my ear ten years at Bottega
Veneta tell me a little bit about
building the brand because batagor is so
connected with bags and especially the
what we call the latticework bag but
you've built many other categories and
certainly it is quite different from
what it was when you came in at the
beginning when I started we cut
everything off that was there and I made
a very small collection focusing only on
handbags and then over time and out of
demand you know like the wallet went
into the back then there was a request
for cosmetic case I for example I never
made belts you know like people said why
don't you make belts and leather coats
because we never didn't have pants so
once we made plans we made belts to hold
up the pants so it was really like a
step-by-step process it was never about
a strategy or a marketing plan
I know you believe in craftsmanship
because you started a school I believe
in 1996 in order to train and to help
the artisans in Italy who make your bags
and leather goods and you wanted to
teach them how to do it and that's a
young generation yes yes yes and we keep
working on this you know we keep pushing
forward and I always believe you know
that being a craftsman down the road is
going to be a very well-paid job because
there won't be that many great craftsmen
around anymore and everybody will like
scream please come to me come to me at
me you know we're losing this
tomorrow you'll also put it surprising
us because I think when those dresses
that were made for the red carpet that
were flowing dresses in these strange
shiny materials it was really a gasp in
the room at your show but how did that
come about and why was it so successful
I mean my broking process my query
process is always the same I start with
Karla that is my inspiration and I go to
material and I always like to look at
material that is like news and so this
was a Japanese material that could only
be laser-cut and that's from there you
know came to crisis like people come to
put it up for a certain saying I like to
Surprise them
I know that your family background is
your father I think is an archetype
maybe your mother too
do you feel that in a way you are
creating fashion architecture with what
you do I'm interested in architecture
very much but I think what I like about
it you know is the process I spend so
much time in my dad's office when I was
a kid and I was so connected like to a
drawing he would make a sketch she would
go into a very technical floorplan and I
could always figure out the floor band
and so on and I think that was such
training for me you know for my process
of thinking I mean those are this
formative years and when you are a
little kid Herr Zeller that sticks to
you
